Function Documentation

void array_deallocater ( Employee *  base_emp,
int  count 
)

Function array_deallocater Takes an array of pointers to structs, and deallocates it. We have to assume that all the pointers have been returned by a previous call to malloc(). If not, segfaults occur, as shown below.

WARNING - THIS FUNCTION WILL RETURN A SEGFAULT.

Parameters:
base_emp the base of the array of pointers to be deallocated
count number of pointers to the struct in array
Returns:
void

Employee* array_duplicater ( Employee *  base_emp,
int  count 
)

Function array_duplicater Takes an array of pointers to structs, and duplicates just the pointers. (shallow copy)

Parameters:
base_emp the base of the array of pointers to be printed
count number of pointers to the struct in array
Returns:
the pointer to base of duplicate array

void pointers_array_printer ( Employee *  base_emp,
int  count 
)

Function pointers_array_printer Takes an array of pointers and a count, and prints out all the structs that the pointers in the array point to.

Parameters:
base_emp the base of the array of pointers to be printed
count number of pointers to structs in the array
Returns:
void

void print_employee ( Employee *  emp_p  ) 

Function print_employee Function that prints the members of a variable of type Employee struct.

Parameters:
emp_p pointer to a struct of type Employee
Returns:
void function only prints members

Employee* random_array_allocater ( int  count  ) 

Function random_array_allocater Takes a count and allocates an array which can hold that many pointers to the struct, then fills each element of the array with a pointer to a newly-created struct filled with random data.

Parameters:
count number of pointers to the struct that the function allocates
Returns:
base of array of pointers
